Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Elucidating migration patterns of Pacific Bluefin Tuna using molecular analysis of stable isotopes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Pacific bluefin Tuna are an important commercial fisheries species, often sold for thousands or millions of dollars in seafood markets. Due to extreme popularity, the species has been greatly overfished, and experienced declines in population of 96% in recent decades. Even though dramatic declines have been experienced, the migration patterns across the Pacific, as well as the life stages in which this migration happens is still unknown for the Pacific bluefin Tuna. This study will investigate the rate of Pacific bluefin Tuna migration through molecular analysis. This research will be conducted at the Fisheries Research Institute in collaboration with Dr. Chi-Lu Sun, who has a long history of research on billfish and other pelagic species as professor at National Taiwan University's Institute of Oceanography.

This project will use stable isotope analysis to better understand Pacific bluefin tuna (PBFT) migration patterns in the North Pacific Ocean. In different ocean regions, local oceanographic conditions affect delta-15N values at the base of the food web (phytoplankton), and these differences propagate up food webs from plankton to prey to predators. Previous studies have demonstrated differences in baseline delta-15N between the eastern and western Pacific Ocean (EPO and WPO). Because of these differences, PBFT can be categorized as residents or recent migrants in the WPO based on low (resident) or high (migrant) delta-15N values. By analyzing samples of PBFT from the WPO, inferences about migration patterns, including the identification of western residents and eastern migrants across a range of size classes will be made. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Science Council of Taiwan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was aimed at using a molecular method, known as stable isotope analysis, to understand the migration patterns of Pacific Bluefin tuna. All living things are composed of specific elements, and variants of those elements, known as isotopes. Isotopes are atoms of an element that contain a different amount neutrons than the normal atom of the element, giving them a different mass. Living things use isotopes with different preferences, a process known as fractionation. Previous studies have shown that Pacific Bluefin tuna on opposite sides of the ocean have different nitrogen fractionation values in various tissue, which leads to migrants and residents having different values in their white muscle tissue. From this data and using a calculation of age, it is possible to figure out how frequently the tuna are migrating across the Pacific Ocean. This has the potential to shape management decisions of this declining species. Goals of this project were to determine how often Pacific Bluefin tuna migrate in order to inform policy decisions. In addition to this research, important international connections were made, an important outcome of the program. Especially considering Bluefin tuna have such a wide range that spans fishing grounds of multiple countries, it's important to foster international relationships when considering the management of this species.
